repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
This is an attempt to resolve #2552 and follows recommendations by @scoder.

Looking forward to your feedback!

comment_data.body: See my other comment regarding the collection, but this doesn't necessarily make `name_node` a `NameNode`. It could also be something like `x.attr` or `x[5]` or whatever else you can assign to. Check `name_node.is_name`, that's the only case we care about for the annotations dict.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -4852,6 +4854,31 @@ def analyse_declarations(self, env):
         if self.doc_node:
             self.doc_node.analyse_target_declaration(cenv)
         self.body.analyse_declarations(cenv)
+        self.analyze_class_annotations(env)
+
+    def analyze_class_annotations(self, env):
+        annotations = []
+        stat_list_node = self.body
+        for stat_node in stat_list_node.stats:
+            if isinstance(stat_node, SingleAssignmentNode):
+                name_node = stat_node.lhs

comment_data.body:
This introduces a circular import. The imports go the other way, `ExprNodes` imports `Nodes`. If you need these here, you'd have to import them locally at need. However, instead, I would suggest letting the `(Py3)ClassNode` in `PyClassDefNode.classobj` do the `__annotations__` building, e.g. through a common function in `ExprNodes.py`. It knows its `class_def_node`, and in fact, all it seems to need is the class' `.body` (and the `.pos` of the class definition).

I'm sorry that I pushed you this way with a comment I made, but the code itself that generates the dict should live in `ExprNodes.py` in the end, regardless of who triggers its execution.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -5,6 +5,8 @@
 from __future__ import absolute_import
 
 import cython
+from .ExprNodes import DictNode, DictItemNode, IdentifierStringNode, NameNode

comment_data.body:
See my other comment regarding the collection, but this looks wrong (a `PassStatNode` shouldn't have an `.expr`), and it's probably due to a hack in `ExprStatNode` that falls on our feet now.

https://github.com/cython/cython/blob/aa8b0d9b89030c0b9ace5698ae5131c623acefa4/Cython/Compiler/Nodes.py#L5502-L5509

We'll need to clean this up at some point, but if we collect the annotations from the symbol table, then this shouldn't hurt us.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -4852,6 +4854,31 @@ def analyse_declarations(self, env):
         if self.doc_node:
             self.doc_node.analyse_target_declaration(cenv)
         self.body.analyse_declarations(cenv)
+        self.analyze_class_annotations(env)
+
+    def analyze_class_annotations(self, env):
+        annotations = []
+        stat_list_node = self.body
+        for stat_node in stat_list_node.stats:
+            if isinstance(stat_node, SingleAssignmentNode):
+                name_node = stat_node.lhs
+            elif isinstance(stat_node, PassStatNode):
+                name_node = stat_node.expr

comment_data.body: `analyse` spells with an `s` in New Zealand (British) English. (The [original creator of the code base](https://www.cosc.canterbury.ac.nz/greg.ewing/) originates from there.)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -4852,6 +4854,31 @@ def analyse_declarations(self, env):
         if self.doc_node:
             self.doc_node.analyse_target_declaration(cenv)
         self.body.analyse_declarations(cenv)
+        self.analyze_class_annotations(env)
+
+    def analyze_class_annotations(self, env):

comment_data.body:
I wonder if this is enough, or if we still need to descend into some tree nodes here. Probably for things like
```
try:
    x: int = may_fail()
except:
    ...
```
Look at `declare_from_annotation()` in `ExprNodes.py`. It already does a part of the job of collecting the annotations in the symbol table (`env.entries`). I think what we should rather do is to make sure the annotation always ends up there, whether we use it internally for static typing or not, and then collect the annotation dict for class scopes from all `Entry`s in `env.entries` that have an annotation. I think that's the cleanest way to do this.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -4852,6 +4854,31 @@ def analyse_declarations(self, env):
         if self.doc_node:
             self.doc_node.analyse_target_declaration(cenv)
         self.body.analyse_declarations(cenv)
+        self.analyze_class_annotations(env)
+
+    def analyze_class_annotations(self, env):
+        annotations = []
+        stat_list_node = self.body
+        for stat_node in stat_list_node.stats:

comment_data.body:
Okay - so want to make sure I follow you correctly - 

1. Let's clean this method up to iterate over `env.entries` and just build the annotation dict from the entries in that collection which have an annotation.
2. Let's make sure `declare_from_annotation()` is collecting valid cases (e.g., don't ignore class body entries).

I believe my latest updates should reflect this!
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -4852,6 +4854,31 @@ def analyse_declarations(self, env):
         if self.doc_node:
             self.doc_node.analyse_target_declaration(cenv)
         self.body.analyse_declarations(cenv)
+        self.analyze_class_annotations(env)
+
+    def analyze_class_annotations(self, env):
+        annotations = []
+        stat_list_node = self.body
+        for stat_node in stat_list_node.stats:

comment_data.body: The comment doesn't match any more. Maybe you could split this into two if-cases again and restore the old comment that went with the module scope case?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1973,32 +1973,26 @@ def coerce_to(self, dst_type, env):
     def declare_from_annotation(self, env, as_target=False):
         """Implements PEP 526 annotation typing in a fairly relaxed way.
 
-        Annotations are ignored for global variables, Python class attributes and already declared variables.
+        Annotations are ignored for global variables and already declared variables.
         String literals are allowed and ignored.
         The ambiguous Python types 'int' and 'long' are ignored and the 'cython.int' form must be used instead.
         """
-        if not env.directives['annotation_typing']:
-            return
-        if env.is_module_scope or env.is_py_class_scope:
-            # annotations never create global cdef names and Python classes don't support them anyway
-            return
         name = self.name
-        if self.entry or env.lookup_here(name) is not None:
-            # already declared => ignore annotation
-            return
-
         annotation = self.annotation
-        if annotation.expr.is_string_literal:
-            # name: "description" => not a type, but still a declared variable or attribute
-            atype = None
-        else:
-            _, atype = annotation.analyse_type_annotation(env)
-        if atype is None:
-            atype = unspecified_type if as_target and env.directives['infer_types'] != False else py_object_type
-        if atype.is_fused and env.fused_to_specific:
-            atype = atype.specialize(env.fused_to_specific)
-        self.entry = env.declare_var(name, atype, self.pos, is_cdef=not as_target)
-        self.entry.annotation = annotation.expr
+        entry = self.entry or env.lookup_here(name)
+        if not entry:
+            if annotation.expr.is_string_literal or env.is_module_scope or not env.directives['annotation_typing']:
+                # name: "description" => not a type, but still a declared variable or attribute

comment_data.body: I prefer making methods generally available over testing for them with `hasattr()`. Is there a case that you ran into where the method was not there? The question is, at which level in the node class hierarchy we would need to introduce the method.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -4852,6 +4853,8 @@ def analyse_declarations(self, env):
         if self.doc_node:
             self.doc_node.analyse_target_declaration(cenv)
         self.body.analyse_declarations(cenv)
+        if hasattr(self.class_result, "analyse_class_annotations"):

comment_data.body:
Well, this method is only available for a `Py3ClassNode`, so I'm hedging my bets against this logic running against a `ClassNode`, which doesn't have this logic... 

I've been thinking that we have a bit of a chicken-and-egg problem here, where we can't analyze the annotations without analyzing the class body, but this needs to be a part of the class body at the end of the analysis. Perhaps it would be better to have this logic live in `StatListNode.analyse_declarations()` and be activated if passed a `ClassScope` instance?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -4852,6 +4853,8 @@ def analyse_declarations(self, env):
         if self.doc_node:
             self.doc_node.analyse_target_declaration(cenv)
         self.body.analyse_declarations(cenv)
+        if hasattr(self.class_result, "analyse_class_annotations"):

comment_data.body: Why is the string not correct here? We are following [PEP-563](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0563/#abstract).
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -9111,7 +9119,7 @@ def analyse_class_annotations(self, env):
                 DictItemNode(
                     entry.pos,
                     key=IdentifierStringNode(entry.pos, value=entry.name),
-                    value=entry.annotation.string
+                    value=entry.annotation.expr

comment_data.body: According to [PEP-526](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0526/#runtime-effects-of-type-annotations), the module scope has an `__annotations__` dict, too. Probably something we can fix up after this PR, though.

comment_data.body: Shouldn't this just be `self.annotation` on the right hand side? (Seems not covered by the tests.)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2055,6 +2057,8 @@ def analyse_target_declaration(self, env):
         if self.entry.as_module:
             # cimported modules namespace can shadow actual variables
             self.entry.is_variable = 1
+        if not self.entry.annotation and self.annotation:
+            self.entry.annotation = self.annotation.expr

comment_data.body:
We shouldn't implement legacy behaviour any more.
```suggestion
# tag: pure37

from __future__ import annotations

from typing import ClassVar
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,19 @@
+# mode: run
+# tag: pure36
+from typing import ClassVar

comment_data.body: I don't think this is the correct behavior either - afaict CPython doesn't support annotating a variable after it's been declared.
comment_data.diff_hunk:

             # cimported modules namespace can shadow actual variables
             self.entry.is_variable = 1
+        if not self.entry.annotation and self.annotation:
+            self.entry.annotation = self.annotation.expr

comment_data.body: True. Why was this change necessary then?

comment_data.body: @scoder it appears that CPython supports custom namespaces for the annotations dict - how would we proceed with this in the compiler? Or is this a feature we should punt on?

Hmm. Well, to implement this correctly, we'd really have to initialise `"__annotations__"` (with an empty dict) at the start, and then look it up each time we see an annotated variable in the code and update whatever mapping we have then. That's a bit more complex than what we have now (although it would certainly use the same infrastructure).

I'd be happy to get the main feature working and merged, and then look at more details later. This can be changed incrementally, if someone feels like doing it.
https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/3838

+        if not entry:

+            if env.is_module_scope:

comment_data.body: Thinking more on this - if we move this logic to `StatListNode`, it will pave the way for re-using this logic for module-scoped annotations with very minimal effort, since they both follow similar chains. Theoretically all we'd need to do then is get rid of the module scope bail out in `NameNode.declare_from_annotation()` and update the branch in `StatListNode.analyse_declarations()` to run on a module scope as well.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -4852,6 +4853,8 @@ def analyse_declarations(self, env):
         if self.doc_node:
             self.doc_node.analyse_target_declaration(cenv)
         self.body.analyse_declarations(cenv)
+        if hasattr(self.class_result, "analyse_class_annotations"):

comment_data.body: Sounds good - I'll re-add the skip with an updated comment and create a ticket for the work.

… except that statement nodes can be wrapped in all sorts of other nodes, not just lined up in a `StatListNode`. No, I think in the end, we'll have to let the nodes with annotations inject themselves into the dict along the way of their execution.

We'll also have to make this work at some point:
```pycon
>>> class C:
...   del __annotations__
...   a: int = 5
... 
>>> C
<class '__main__.C'>
>>> C.a
5
>>> C.__annotations__
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
AttributeError: type object 'C' has no attribute '__annotations__'
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:

         if self.doc_node:
             self.doc_node.analyse_target_declaration(cenv)
         self.body.analyse_declarations(cenv)
+        if hasattr(self.class_result, "analyse_class_annotations"):

comment_data.body: I've added a new issue to address this behavior and others, such as the custom namespace object: #3839
comment_data.diff_hunk:

+        if hasattr(self.class_result, "analyse_class_annotations"):

comment_data.body: Covered in #3839
As a safety measure, I added a no-op `analyse_annotations()` to `ClassNode` so that this check is no longer necessary.
comment_data.diff_hunk:

             self.doc_node.analyse_target_declaration(cenv)
         self.body.analyse_declarations(cenv)
+        if hasattr(self.class_result, "analyse_class_annotations"):

comment_data.body:
Better be explicit about what we're referring to.
```suggestion
    @skip("Not currently supported: https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/3839")
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -486,6 +486,7 @@ class Cbad2(C):
                 x: int
                 x.y: list = []
 
+    @skip("Not currently supported: #3839")

commit.message: Add support for PEP 526 `__annotations__` in class body.
Push no-op `analyse_annotations` up to common ancestor.
Fix attribute assertions for existing tests.
Update variable annotations test for class annotations analysis
Handle SyntaxError for __future__ import in unsupported python versions
Use the correct tags for class annotation tests.

repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

title: Add support for PEP 526 `__annotations__` in class body.
